note.p: Alexander Mosby Clayton was a judge and political figure in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on January 15, 1801, in Campbell County, Virginia, Clayton studied law and became a practicing attorney in that state in 1823. He moved to Arkansas Territory in 1832 to accept an appointment from President Andrew Jackson as a judge in the territory’s superior court. Five years later, he relocated to Mississippi. Clayton was elected to Mississippi’s High Court of Errors and Appeals (the precursor to the state’s Supreme Court) in 1842 and served until 1852. During that same period in Mississippi, Clayton was appointed the first president of the University of Mississippi Board of Trustees, and served in that role until 1852. In 1853, Clayton received an appointment from President Franklin Pierce to be consul in Havana, Cuba. He served one year in that role, and then returned to Mississippi to practice law.

During the 1850s, Clayton became an outspoken proponent of secession in response to northern anti-slavery activities. He was a delegate to the Nashville Convention, a meeting of southern delegates to debate the political dispute over slavery in territories gained from the Mexican-American War, and promoted a hardline stance, including disunion, to protect slaveholding interests. Ten years later, in January 1861, at Mississippi's secession convention in the wake of Abraham Lincoln’s election to the president, Clayton again advocated secession, and wrote the state’s declaration of reasons for separating from the Union. He was then selected to represent the state in the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States during the spring of 1861. Following his short time in the Confederate Congress, Clayton served as a Confederate district court judge during the Civil War.

A year after the war ended, Clayton received an appointment as a circuit judge in Mississippi. He held that position for three years before being removed by federal officials in 1869, following ratification of the Fourteenth Amendment and its provision that prohibited previous U.S. officials who had supported the Confederacy from holding military or civil office. He returned to private law practice, as well as worked as director of the Mississippi Central Railroad.
Clayton died on September 30, 1889. He was married to Barbara Barker and had at least two children who survived to adulthood. He is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Leslie H. Southwick, “Alexander Clayton [1801-1889] Judge,” Mississippi Encyclopedia)

note.p: George Emrick Harris was an attorney, a Confederate officer, and politician in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on January 6, 1827, in Orange County, North Carolina, Harris lived in Tennessee and then moved to Mississippi as a young man. He studied law and became a practicing attorney in 1854. When the Civil War broke out, he volunteered for Confederate military service. He served as an officer in the Eighteenth Mississippi Cavalry Battalion.

After the Civil War, Harris joined the Republican Party. He served as a district attorney in 1865 and 1866, and then won election to the U.S. House of Representatives for Mississippi, serving two terms, from 1870 to 1873. At the end of his second congressional term, Harris was appointed Mississippi’s attorney general and served in that role from 1873 to 1877. His last notable public office was as lieutenant governor of Mississippi from 1877 to 1879.
Harris died on March 19, 1911, in Washington, D.C. He was married to Harriet McAllister and had seven children. He is buried in Oak Hill Cemetery in Washington, D.C.
(Wikipedia; Historical Data Systems, Inc., American Civil War Research Database; FindaGrave; “Harris, George emrick, 1827-1911,” Biographical Directory of the United States Congress)

Currently located in Marshall County, Holly Springs was founded in 1836 in what was then Monroe County. When Marshall County was created on March 1, 1836, Holly Springs became its county seat. (Rowland, Mississippi, 874; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: Plantations are farms that typically grow cash crops, and often specialize in a single product, such as cotton, tobacco, or sugar cane. Plantation farming continues in various parts of the world in the twenty-first century, especially for crops like coffee beans, rubber trees, and cocoa. In American history the term plantation is most often associated with estates in the American south. Historical descriptions of plantations generate images of large farming operations. However, even moderately-sized southern farms that planted cash crops were sometimes referred to as plantations.

Southern plantations before the Civil War were strongly tied to the institution of slavery. As profit-driven agricultural operations, plantations required large numbers of laborers. This fed the demand for African slave importation to the British colonies in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, and bolstered the defense of slavery among southern planters in the nineteenth century. Plantation crops varied by region within the south, with rice being popular in Georgia and South Carolina along the Atlantic coast, tobacco being an early cash crop in Virginia, and then—after the invention of the cotton gin at the end of the eighteenth century which quickly separated seeds from the cotton fibers—the boom in cotton growing across the Deep South.

By 1860, there were approximately 46,200 plantations across the south. More than 20,000 had twenty to thirty slaves. Only about 2,300, or five percent, had one hundred or more slaves. The enslaved African Americans carried out most of the farming, construction, and domestic work. The plantations were their home. The same was not always true for the plantation owners. The very large operations frequently had wealthy absentee owners, who resided in cities or other states, leaving plantation supervision responsibilities to hired white overseers. Smaller plantation owners usually lived on their property, but almost always in separate buildings from the enslaved laborers. Slave cabins, or slave quarters, were a ubiquitous part of a plantation. They represented the heart of the laborers’ community on the property, but were usually of basic construction and few amenities.

Following the abolition of slavery after the Civil War, many freed people continued to live on plantations. Sharecropping became a popular arrangement between the landowners and the laborers. The property was often divided into plots with tenants assigned to certain sections. The system involved a contract or arrangement which allowed the laborer, or tenant, to keep a portion of the crop they raised. The system was abused, and developed a negative reputation for the level of poverty many sharecroppers (mostly Black, but some white) experienced on plantations in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Representatives of the Freedmen’s Bureau sought to protect Black sharecroppers by regulating contracts during Reconstruction, but the withdrawal of federal officials after 1876 left many African American tenants more subject to unfair sharecropping contracts on the old plantations. (Wikipedia)

When the 13th Amendment abolished slavery, it failed to abolish involuntary servitude. The amendment included a loophole banning involuntary servitude "except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted" (Library of Congress). White southerners in the post-emancipation South, concerned about both the availability of labor and the freedom of African Americans, manipulated this clause and turned to convict leasing to entrench long standing racial hierarchies.

Immediately after the war, many states passed "Black Codes" or laws severely limiting African Americans' rights. Under these codes and other similar laws passed in the decades following the Civil War, African Americans could be arrested for any number of petty crimes, including vagrancy (functionally construed to mean any act of social mobility not approved by a white person) or theft (in Mississippi a felony if exceeding $10 worth of goods). Widespread racism and stereotypes about Black criminality led to a dramatic expansion in the population of imprisoned individuals and an overwhelming number of African Americans within that population. Many states leased those convicted persons to private companies or individuals for their labor, and in certain cases lessees had been the pre-emancipation enslaver of the leased.

Laborers worked in a variety of settings including shipbuilding and timber cutting, yet the most prominent form in states like Mississippi remained large-scale agricultural work. The convict lease system was incredibly dangerous and difficult for those who lived through it, as leased persons faced unsafe working conditions, inadequate living conditions, abuse from lessees, and grueling work schedules. Given these circumstances, the ready availability of imprisoned laborers, and the callousness of lessees and state officials, the mortality rate among convict laborers was incredibly high.

Certain states ceased leasing imprisoned persons to individuals or private companies in the late nineteenth century, only to continue using that labor on state-funded infrastructure projects like road or highway construction until, in some cases, World War II. Southern individuals and states thereby continued to increase their wealth through the coerced labor of African Americans while perpetuating anti-Black racism and laying the foundations of the modern prison-industrial complex (Library of Congress; Mississippi Encyclopedia).

In the wake of the Civil War, many states turned to convict leasing to bolster infrastructural repair and to maintain long standing racial hierarchies. Like many other southern states, Mississippi instituted a convict leasing program, and in 1876 the state passed the Leasing Act (commonly known as the “Pig Law”), which sentenced anyone who stole property valued at $10 or greater up to five years in prison and quadrupled the prison population, with Black prisoners comprising approximately 85% of inmates. The state most frequently leased convicted persons to individuals, primarily to perform agricultural work on cotton farms.

However, the state also leased incarcerated persons to private companies, such as the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad Company, and companies subjected convict-laborers to excruciating working conditions with little shelter, sustenance, or medical care. While companies and private individuals leased enslaved workers during the antebellum era, enslavers expected “their human chattel to be returned alive and in good working condition” (Sturkey, Hattiesburg). However, this expectation was virtually nonexistent in postwar convict leasing programs. The death toll therefore grew to staggering heights. In response, Mississippi cancelled Gulf & Ship Island’s contract in December 1888 and ceased leasing convicts to private companies in 1890. However, the state and individual counties and towns continued to use convict labor for public works projects and at the state’s penitentiary at Parchman plantation well into the twentieth century (Mississippi Encyclopedia).

gloss.p: Historically free African Americans included people who were both African American and lived as and/or were legally free before the American Civil War. They may or may not have previously been enslaved. In recognition of African American military service during the Revolutionary War, a number of states moved to gradually abolish slavery leading to a growing body of free African Americans.

Freedom, however, did not mean citizenship, and despite efforts by free Black activists to settle this question and affirm their citizenship, it was largely left to state lawmakers who otherwise failed to settle the question. Consequently, during the Antebellum era, each southern state passed different laws governing the place and rights of free African Americans. Home to the nation's largest free African American community, for example, Baltimore, Maryland registered 25,000 free Black residents by 1850. (Martha S. Jones, Birthright Citizens: A History of Race and Rights in Antebellum America, p. 13)

In another example, South Carolina's Act of 1820 distinguished between those freed before and after 1820, and classified free African Americans as "denizens," which limited citizenship rights by a series of Black Codes. In response to rebellions, numerous states passed legal restrictions that made manumission virtually impossible by the mid-nineteenth century. Loved ones who purchased family members were forced to legally hold them in bondage, leading to a body of people who "were free by practice, but not by law." (Amrita Chakrabarti Myers, Forging Freedom, 3–4, 207)

Unlike South Carolina, Mississippi's judiciary ruled that “free negroes . . . are to be regarded as alien enemies or strangers prohibited, and without the pale of comity, and incapable of acquiring or maintaining property in this State which will be recognized by our courts.” (Heirn v. Bridault, 37 Miss. 209, 224–25, 1859 in Jones, Birthright Citizens, p. 213) The state's strict provisions on manumission led to an extremely small population of free African Americans (773 people by 1860) during the antebellum era ("Free Blacks in Antebellum Mississippi," Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Newly freed African Americans includes people who were enslaved but became free by the passage of the Emancipation Proclamation and/or the Thirteenth Amendment. While neither was comprehensive, the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863 freed the enslaved in territories under rebellion, and later the Thirteenth Amendment of 1865 abolished slavery altogether, except when used as a punishment for those who committed a crime and did not apply to Native Nations who practices slavery. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia) In the CWRGM collection, African Americans after December 6, 1865 are classified as historically free or newly freed.

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary classifies "a person who lives in the U.S. and is a member of a race of people with dark skin that originally came from Africa" as African American, but both the nineteenth-century and modern constructions are more complex (Cambridge Dictionary). Common nineteenth-century racial categories such as "mulatto" referred to persons with both white and black ancestry, and the experiences of mixed-race persons varied based on complexion, degree of African ancestry, and the region in which they lived. In antebellum cities with large populations of free Blacks, the degree of one's African ancestry could determine what rights one possessed or did not possess, and people with lighter skin tones were often considered to be white; this ended under "one drop rule" during the Jim Crow system.

Like skin tone, the ethnicity implied by the term "African American" is also problematically broad, as "naming people only by the continent of their origin and ignoring their ethnic identity is a consequence of time and space" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 5). The experience of slavery complicated the term by attempting to strip people of their original distinct African ethnic identities such as Ibo or Ndongan, classifying all persons of African descent together under one term, infusing that term with negative connotation, and disregarding the complex and rich linguistic, cultural, and ethnic histories of varied African people. However, many Black Americans have reclaimed the term "African American" and infused it with positive connotations. One scholar argues that "in using the term 'African Americans,' Black Americans accent the part of their heritage that is not American" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 4).

CWRGM — acknowledging the multiplicity of the term's meanings and connotations — includes multiracial and multiethnic people of African descent under the "African Americans" social identifiers subject tag to reflect the diversity of the African American experience and to ensure that the experiences of African Americans of mixed races and ethnicities are discoverable as they are rarely distinguished further in the letters. In the absence of other references, CWRGM also tags racial slurs targeted at African Americans — which were common in nineteenth century documents with white authors — under the "African Americans" tag. CWRGM recognizes the historic and present harm caused by such language and does not condone its use but tags these terms only to ensure the rich history of African Americans are discoverable within the collection.

gloss.p: While the Cambridge Dictionary defines death as “the end of life,” CWRGM employs this subject tag to refer to human deaths only, both actual and hypothetical. (Cambridge Dictionary)

The nation experienced mass loss of life (approximately 2% of the population) during the American Civil War, which changed the way Americans viewed death and resulted in its reconceptualization in highly bureaucratized ways. Often wartime dead were buried without their names and sometimes in poorly-dug graves, which created a powerful, profound social and cultural dislocation for their surviving loved ones. During the 19th century, Americans understood dying as a social and religious experience, and desired a "good death," which they defined as at home surrounded by family, but these ideals were unattainable in war. Consequently, Americans learned to cope with death and memorialize it in new ways. Unionists encouraged the federal government and ex-Confederates pushed their respective state governments to create and fund national cemeteries, rebury deceases soldiers and veterans, and establish veterans' and widows' pensions. These new responses to death were more bureaucratized, nationalistic, and secularized. Wartime and post-war death was also highly impacted by race, as white supremacists desecrated the graves of Union buried in the South, especially the bodies of African Americans who served in U.S. Colored Troops and the white officers that led them, revealing post-war sectionalism and strains on reconciliation. (Drew Gilpin Faust, This Republic of Suffering)

div.p: State of Mississippi

At a Circuit Court for Marshall County begun & held at the Court Room in the City of Holly Springs on the fourth Monday being the 28th day of September 1868 present the Hon Alex M. Clayton Judge of the 7th Judicial District, John R M Carroll Sheriff of said County and George B. Meyers Clerk of said County when the follwing proceedings were had in a certain cause heretofore pending and determined in said Court, wherein
The State of Miss. is Plaintiff
62 [gap] v
Henry Miller (Cold.) is Defendant
True Bill

The Grand Jury elected and empannedled & sworn for the County of Marshall on the 28th day of September 1867 filed their true bill in the words and figures following to wit" The State of Mississ-ippi Marshall County Circuit Court September Term 1867 The Grand Jurors for the said State of Mississippi, elected empannelled, sworn and charged to inquire in and for the body of the County of Marshall aforesaid, upon their oath do present that Henry Miller Col'd late of said County on the 1st day of September in the year of our Lord One Thousand Eight Hundred and Sixty Seven in the County of Marshall & State aforesaid with force and arms in the peace

of God and of the said State in and upon one Priscilla Bowen Colored, then and there being did make an assault and her the said Priscilla Bowen Colored witfully, wickedly & feloneously did kill and slay contrary to the form of the Statute in such ease made and provided and against the peace and dignity of the State of Mississippi

(Signed) [gap] G. E. Harris
District Attorney of the 7th Judicial District
of Mississippi"

Endorsed "A true bill J. H. Alexeander
Forman of the Grand Jury"
"Filed Sept 28/678 G B Meyers Clerk"

On the 28th day of September A D 1867 the pris=oner was arraigned as follows" Comes the District Attorney as well as the Defendent who being solemnly arraigned upon the indictment filed against him is allowed by the Court time to enter his plea to said bill of indictment and there upon comes into Court Mary Bowen Cold. a witness on the part of the State who acknowled-ges herself to owe and be indebted to the State of Mississippi in the sum of two hundred dollars to be levied of her estate but this recognizance to be void provided the said Mary Bowen shall make her appearance in & before this Court from day to day of each term to give evidence on the part of the State in this case & shall not depart hence without leave of the Court."
Recognizance

"This cause is continued and thereupon comes the Defendant with Robt T. Bowen his surety who acknowledge themselves each to owe & be indebted to the State of Mississippi in the sum of five hun=dred dollars to be levied of their estates respective-ly; but this recognizance is to be void if the Defen=dant Henry Miller F. M. do make his appearance in & before the Court at the next term to be held at the Court Room in the city of Holly Springs on the fourth Monday in March 1868 & from day to day of that term & from term to term & from day to day of each term and shall not depart thence without leave of the Court"
Monday march 30 th 1865
Continuance
"This cause is continued on affidavit of Defendant"

p.del: not depart hence without leave of the Court."

div.p: Affidavit for Continuance

On the 30th of March 1868 Defendent filed his affidavit for continuance in words & figures as follows" The Defendant cannot go safely to trial at this Term of the Court because of the absence of Rachael Freedman a witness in his behalf who has been regularly subpoenaed and is not now absent by his procurement or consent. By this witness he expects to prove that a few days before the fatal shooting occurred he came home with the gun, and after reaching home in the presence of said witness shot off the gun & placed it on the rack empty, that afterwards—within a week when he took the gun down the accident occurred. Affidavit not having in the mean Time loaded the guns & believing it was still unloaded. Affiant is advised that it is ma=terial for him to prove that he put up the gun unloaded as aforesaid & there is no other wit=ness but the said Freeman by whom he can prove that fact. He also expects to prove by her that he was not angry, & that it was purely accidental. He expects to have this witness here by the next term of the Court. This application is not made for delay but that justice may be done
Sworn to & subscribed this the 30th Mch 1868. G. B. Myers Clk
Henry Miller" his xmark

And afterwards to-wit on Monday the 5th of October 1868 and on the trial of the above case the following charges were given to the jury "Involuntary manslaughter is when a man doing an unlawful act not amounting to felony by accident Kills another."
"If the ^jury believe from the^ evidence that the accused did kill the deceased by culpable negligence and with=out authority of law they will find him guilty"
"Given G B Myers Clerk"
Verdict of Jury

"And in the same day a verdict was rendered as follows Comes again the District Attorney as well as the Defendant who having been arraigned on at ^a^ former day of this term of this Court and time granted him to plead and come also a jury to-wit Wm Diggs & eleven others who being sworn well and truly to try the issue joined between the State and the Defendant on their oath say they find the Defendant guilty as charged and recommend him to the mercy of the Court."

And again on Tuesday October 6th 1868 the prisoner was sentenced as follows" Comes again the District Attorney as well as the Defendant against when a verdict of guilty was rendered by the jury in a former day of this term, it is therefore considered by the Court that for such his offense he be remanded to prison & that he be taken thence by the Sheriff of this County to the
State Penitentiary to be therein confined and Kept at labor for the full period of two years from and after this date and that the cost of this prosecution be levied of his estate."
And afterwards on the 7th day of October 1868 Defendant made a motion for a new trial which was by the Court overruled as follows
Motion for new trial

"Comes again the District attorney & the Defendant who has been convicted in a former day of this term & sentenced to two years in the State Penitentia-ry & Defendant by attorney moves the Court to set aside the verdict of the Court & grant him a new trial which motion is by the Court overruled to which judgment of the Court in overruling said motion & refusing to grant said new trial Defendant by attorney excepts & tenders his bill of exceptions which is signed sealed & ordered to be made part of the record."
Bill of Exceptions

And therefore Draft filed his bid of exceptions in words and figures following to-wit " Be it remem=bered, that in the trial of this cause the State proved that Rachel Bowen was examined as a witness on the part of the State before the Justice who committed the accused for the offense for the commission of which he was on trial, and that she has since died that the testimony she gave on said examination the State was then prepared and able fully to prove & therefore the testimony of said deceased witness which was fully proved and identified was

submtted to the jury and was as follows: said witness said, "she was present when Priscilla (decd) was killed by the shot from a gun in the hands of Henry Miller, in this County, on Sunday evening Sept 1 st 1867. at Bowen's place Henry reached up for the gun she, Rachel, told him (Henry) not to take the gun down. Henry took his hand off the gun, but soon took the gun down, cocked it and fired, and Priscilla fell, hit in the left side. Henry was in a good humor, when he took the gun down. Satisfied he had no in=tention to do any harm so far as I could judge."

Mary Bowen was next introduced by the State as a witness who on being duly worn testified, "that she and Priscilla Miller went to the house of the accused, Henry Miller on Mr Robt Bowen's plan-tation in Marshall County Missi: on or about the 1st of Sept 1867; that they and Rachel Bowen and the said Defendant were the only persons in the house that under the bed there were some watermelons belong-ing to the Defendant; that witness took one of the melons and Priscilla was about taking another when the accused objected to her taking it, and said if she did take it he would kick her all over the room. Priscilla replied that she was not afraid of his kicking her; accused then replied that he would shoot her, Priscilla then replied she was not afraid of his shooting her. Rachel Bowen who who was in the room lying on the bed, then said to the said Defendant, "dont take that gun down"

Defendant had then reached his hand to-wards the gun which was over the door—witness looked around, & Defendant did not then take the gun, witness turned away and in a moment the gun fired. At this time witness was standing with her back to the parties; when she looked around again she saw Priscilla in the act of falling, and as she fell, she said "Oh Henry." She died almost immediately. Witness farther proved that about taking the watermelons there was no hard feelings be-tween accused and Rachel ^Priscilla^ that she knew of; that they were in good humor and laughing at the time. Defendants counsel then asked the witness if the ac=cused said anything and what, when Priscilla said "Oh Henry." and was in the act of falling, to which question objection was made on the part of the State on the ground that after the firing of the gun and the Killing, what the accused said or did, could not be introduced as evidence on his behalf. The counsel of the accused then stated that he expected to prove by the witness that, when Priscilla said " Oh Henry" and was in the act of falling the accused, exclaimed "I thought the gun was not loaded", and seemed greatly surprised, & that as a part of the resgistae, he submitted that the said exclamation and the surprise manifisted by the accused were competent testimony—The objection to the asking of said question and the introduction of said proposed testimony was sustained by the Court, and it was excluded, to which opinion and judgment of

the Court is sustaining said objection and excluding from the Jury said proposed testimony, the accused by his counsel excepted at the time, and to save the benefit thereof, presented this his Bill of exceptions. The testimony having been closed the Jury retired and returned into Court with a vertict of guilty and thereupon the accused by his counsel, made a motion for a new trial on these grounds.

1st The Court erred in excluding from the jury the proof offered that immediately after the firing of the gun, and as the deceased in the act of falling said "Oh Henry," the accused said he "thought the gun was not loaded,"

2 nd Because the Court erred in not allowing proof of the surprise of the accused as shown in his manner, and what he said immedi=ately after the firing the gun and as the deceased was in the act of falling Which motion the Court overruled, to which opinion and judgment of the Court in overruling said motion the Defendant excepted, and to save the benefit thereof presented this his bill of exceptions, to be signed and sealed by the Court and made a part of the record of the case which was accordingly done.

Alex M Clayton [Seal]
Judge & C"
